awd_titl_txt: Facility Support: High-Resolution X-ray Computed Tomography Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will continue NSF support of the University of Texas High-Resolution X-ray Computed Tomography Facility (UTCT) as a shared multi-user facility supporting geoscience research. Computed tomography (CT) is ideally suited for many geological applications, as it nondestructively creates 3D imagery of the interiors of rocks, fossils, meteorites and other materials.  Successful application of this technique requires both advanced instrumentation and experienced operators to optimize data acquisition and processing, and the ability to design and implement rigorous and well-targeted 3D data analysis strategies. UTCT serves both as a source of high-quality data for investigators without access to CT instrumentation, and as a repository of experience and expertise in all aspects of CT data acquisition and analysis, both through individual consultation and collaboration and by teaching short courses. Having UTCT as a national resource thus reduces the number of instruments the nation needs to conduct CT-involved research, and helps those instruments that we do invest in to be used to best advantage.  Advances in CT data acquisition and processing at UTCT have also been used in many other fields.  UTCT also provides leadership in management and curation of CT data sets, through our long-term investment in the DIGIMORPH digital library. 

This project will provide partial support of the UTCT facility operating expenses for the next three years, including staff, equipment maintenance, and computing infrastructure. In addition, funds will be used to upgrade the primary CT instrument to enhance data processing speed and the flexibility of the detector gantry to enable scans of larger objects and scanning at higher resolution.  The facility support will allow for timely and high-quality service for a large user base; development of new CT methodologies; and expansion of short courses in HRXCT data acquisition, visualization, and quantification.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported continued operation of the University of Texas High-Resolution X-ray Computed Tomography Facility (UTCT) as an NSF community facility.  X-ray CT is a non-destructive technology that allows investigators to see the insides of solid, opaque objects, making it an ideal method for studying irreplaceable or one-of-a-kind samples.  It is used across the geological sciences, and in many allied sciences as well, including biology, anthropology, and engineering.

Community facility support from NSF was vital in allowing us to retain our experienced and innovative staff, maintain and improve our instrumentation, and provide top-quality data and analysis for the geological and wider scientific community. With this support, UTCT continued to make top quality high-resolution X-ray CT data, and the expertise necessary to exploit it widely and inexpensively, available to the geoscience community, and to encourage and facilitate its increasing use for cutting-edge research.  The stability provided by NSF funding was especially important in allowing our operations to continue through the many challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.

During the grant period, UTCT helped 234 different investigators, 65% of which were from outside of the University of Texas.  We conducted 5453 hours of invoiced scanning, and spent hundreds of hours more development new scanning techniques and protocols, and doing proof-of-principle test scans for prospective users.  Over four years, we only experienced approximately 120 days of instrument down time, though the pandemic was far more disruptive.

From 2018-2022, UTCT data appeared in 412 peer-reviewed publications.  The majority of these were in geology and paleontology, but also included research in biology, anthropology, and engineering, reflecting the diverse range of researchers in need of our analytical capabilities.   A small sampling of the research we enabled is provided in the images associated with this report.

This project also supported 2-day and 3-day short courses on CT data processing provided for students and faculty, usually in person but remote during COVID-19.  We offered separate courses on geology and paleontology applications.
